item.description:
In Der verflixte Zaubertrank players are magician assistants who need to bring together the ingredients needed to complete potions – but to do this, they can use a little magic of their own to double up on ingredients they already have.

Each player has four cauldron tiles – two with slits in the top, two with slits in the bottom – that can be assembled into two cauldrons; a player also has two fireplace tiles on which the completed cauldrons sit as well as eight firestones. To set up the game, 22 magic ingredient tiles that show mushrooms, spiders, frogs and the assistants themselves are shuffled, placed into two even stacks, then covered with a "book" cover.

To start the first round, the book cover is "opened" so that four ingredient tiles are revealed (the "recipe"). Players then race to assemble their cauldrons and place them on their fireplaces; after doing so, they then rotate the fireplaces and mark the locations from which they can see the ingredients needed to complete the potion. The cauldrons tiles have mirrors on half of them, so a mushroom on one tile might be reflected in the mirror, thus giving a player two mushrooms for a potion. Similarly, a half mushroom can be made whole with a mirror.

Once a player thinks he has marked exactly the number and type of ingredients he needs, he ends the round. If he created the potion correctly, he moves his pawn two spaces on the track; otherwise everyone else advances one space on the track. Players then disassemble their cauldrons, flip over two ingredients tiles (thereby showing a new recipe), and start the next round.

If an assistant shows up on an ingredient tile, that player advances two spaces after cooking ends that round. At a certain point in the game, a mouse comes to aide the player in last place, providing all the mushrooms that player needs.

Der verflixte Zaubertrank ends when all recipes have been used or a player reaches the final space on the track. The player who advances the farthest on the track wins the game.

4 Kings is a card game for 2 to 7 players. It can be played with a standard deck of cards, or with the print & play cards (available in the links section).

The objective is to use the unique abilities of the cards you are dealt, (or the cards you choose, if using the Card Drafting variant) to capture other cards, while at the same time avoiding the loss of your own highest valued cards. If any player captures all 4 Kings, that player wins.

A player chosen at random will start out the game with a card of his choice. After this, each player attempts to use the abilities of their cards to capture opponents' cards in play while at the same time limiting the risk of losing their highest valued cards.

After playing a card, until the start of a player's next turn, his card is at risk of being captured. At the end of play, if no player has captured all 4 kings, the player holding the highest value of cards collected wins.

item.description:
From Dunwich to Innsmouth, from the halls of Miskatonic University to the Charles Dexter Ward at Arkham Asylum, trouble is in the air. The stars are almost right, and terrors from beyond space and time are beginning to break through. When Cthulhu rises, we're all doomed – but whose downfall will be the most entertaining?

Cthulhu Gloom takes the game play of Atlas' Gloom and puts a Lovecraftian spin on it. Each player controls a group of protagonists, and your goal is to make them as miserable and insane as possible – preferably with them dying quickly while your opponents' heroes remain sane and (at a minimum) alive. In the publisher's description: "While your characters Gibber With Ghouls and Learn Loathsome Lore to earn negative points, you'll encourage your opponents to be Analyzed by Alienists and to Just Forget About the Fungus to pile on positive points. When one group finally falls prey to the interdimensional doom that awaits us all, the player whose characters have suffered the most wins."

As in Gloom, the cards in Cthulhu Gloom are transparent, allowing you to stack multiple modifier cards on a character card to alter its stats or undo what an opponent has done to you. While Cthulhu Gloom can be played on its own or combined with Gloom and its many expansions, it does introduce two new types of cards:

• Story cards can be in play from the start of the game, and the first player to meet a Story card's conditions – e.g., drawing the attention of The King in Yellow or heeding The Call of Cthulhu – claims the card and gains its benefits (or drawbacks).

• Transformation cards mutate a character for the remainder of the game, no matter which modifiers might come its way later. What's more, the character's image is replaced with "something hideous and slimy". You'd expect no less really...

name.value: Tout le monde veut prendre sa place

item.description:
The board game from the French show of the same name on France 2 --
"Everyone wants to take his place"

The goal of the game is to earn points to challenge and defeat the champion in the final step of the game.

At the beginning of the game a player is selected to be the champion (or the champion of the previous game) and wait for an opponent.

During the first two steps of the game, other players answer series of questions and earn points to qualify them to the final.Players may choose to answer directly, or choose between four possible answers or between two possible answers, influencing the amount of points they earn.

In the third step of the game, the player with the most points faces the champion defeat him and take his place!

Will you be the first to finish in Weird Tales? It's a race to the end (card) as players pit their story skills against each other to emerge as the victorious storyteller!

Weird Tales is a storytelling game where players help to complete a story using cards in their hand. Every card will earn you points; the one with the most points at the end of the game is the winner!

Weird Tales is a storytelling card game for 3-6 players, aged 10 years and up. Earn turn, a player uses one of the five cards in his hand to contribute to the story being told. Players are awarded points based on the cards used each turn; points are tabulated at the end of the game. The winner is one with the most points!

When the Navy Walked is a miniature rules set that covers an alternate history from the 1872 Victorian era to the 1909 Edwardian Industrial Age. It is a springboard for imagination and a high-level game of tactics and battles set amongst a 'what if' world inspired by the classic authors of Victorian Science Fiction and Retro Science Fiction. In WTNW players take the reins of generals and command massive armies of steam driven behemoths. In the end, the thunder that cascades across the battlefield to settle in the souls of the fighting men will only be assuaged with the assistance of the landship.

When the Navy Walked is the first in a series of books that will outline the story and history behind this alternate Earth, its culture and the rules for fighting massive battles. In future supplements players will have the opportunity to play through various alternate historical scenarios, including the colonization of Africa and the deep, dark folds of the Aether. So grab your goggles and your Aethertech and get ready for a good time filled with steam and adventure!

link.value: When the Navy Walked Airships and Skypirates
When the Navy Walked: Conflict On Mars
When the Navy Walked: Earthin – The Hollow Earth

item.description:
Executive Manager- A Manpower Game

Executive Manager is a business game designed for 2 to 4 players. In the game the players are put in the position of a manager who must achieve a certain production by the end of a month. To achieve this output the player must maintain a staff of 5 workers. His permanent staff consists of Mr. Noshow, Miss Tardy, Mr. Fumble, Miss Vacation, and Miss Sniffles. When members of this rather unreliable staff are out they may be replaced with Manpower employees.

Game Equipment

Game Board in 3 Interlocking Sections
Employee Tokens (Noshow, Tardy, etc. and Manpower Personnel)
Dice
Play Money
Yellow Fortune Cards
Wooden Tokens
Market Price Cards

Laboratory Syntesis! A team of researchers working on the study of new proteins. But a procedural error caused the Genetic Material discarded, were free to recombination with some types of dangerous viruses. Now, besides the study, researchers also must deal with the activation of these viruses and learn undoing the consequences of these activations, which may directly affect all searches. And in this context that best take advantage of the situation, the winner is ...
 In Syntesis, players will have to create one or more proteins. To do this you have to create a correct sequence of amino acids that determine each protein. For this, Nitrogen Bases Adenine, thymine, cytosine and guanine must be placed in proper sequence. But watch out, because viruses can be activated, which may interfere with the search for all players.

This game has 6 tanks trying to be the last one alive on a board consisting of a 10x10 grid.

Each turn you select 3 of your 21 cards that will determine the three actions you are allowed to take that turn.
Move, retreat, turn, turn your turret or fire! 
Mountains and land mines post obstacles for your movement and fire, and you will have to try to deduce your opponent's moves, since you have to pick your cards at the same time.

Beware, if your tank is hit, you'll have to discard seven of those cards and wont have that much choices, get hit three times and you're out!


El juego consiste en 6 tanques intentando ser el último en pie en un tablero tipo grilla de 10x10.

Cada turno los jugadores eligen cuales 3 de los 21 movimientos posibles de su tanque van a realizar (avanzar, retroceder, girar, girar el cañon, disparar).
Hay montañas y minas que obstaculizan el desplazamiento, y un lindo juego de deducción al tener que adivinar los movimientos de tu oponente porque las cartas a usar se eligen al principio y se van ejecutando después en el orden del turno

Si golpean a tu tanque, tenés que descartar 7 de las 21 cartas de movimiento. Otro golpe y solo te quedarán 7 cartas, al tercer golpe el tanque es destruido!

item.description:
Powerplay was published in spielbox 1991 #6.
The game is played on a 4x4 game board. Each player has 4 round-shaped and 4 square-shaped tokens numbered from 1 to 4. The tokens have two sides, one of them with a black frame. Each player, alternately, should put one of his tokens on a free field on the game board. When all fields are occupied, it's time to check the effects of each token on the opponent's neighboring tokens. The square pieces work horizontally and vertically whereas the round tokens work diagonally. A token is considered conquered, if the score of the pieces surrounding it is higher than its own value, and it is turned onto its black framed side. The winner is the player whit the most points, i. e., a higher difference between the points of the pieces he conquests and the points of your pieces conquered by the opponent.

One of the players plays the "Burros" and the other player tries to get them back into the "Corral", before they can reach the "Cave". The player for the Burros, spins first, and spins 3 times for each Burro, moving them the amount of spaces indicated on the spinner. From this point of the game, the Burros receive 1 spin for each marker, spinning for the leading marker first, second next, etc., and moves each forward the amount on the spinner. After the Burros each have their turn, the other player spins again as before, moves all the Burros backwards the amount spun. If a Burro moves back into the Corral, or if he lands on a space marked "Trap", remove this marker from the playing board. if of the Burros reach the Cave, the Burros win the game. If all of the Burros are caught, they lose the game.

link.value: Tee Pee Toys, Jessup Paper Box Co.

item.description:
According to the rules:

The Object of the game is to be the only player not to become bankrupt.

To Set Up the game each player chooses a token and begins on the start square. Each player is given two each of the $500s, $100s and $50s; six of the $20s; five each of the $10s, $5s and $1s. During the game the bank cannot go broke. The bank sells and handles the bankruptcies of the businesses and charges for the customers. If the bank runs out of customers, no more can be obtained until some are sold back to the bank.

To Win the game, a player has to be the only player not to declare personal bankruptcy. When a player owes more money than he can raise by selling customers and bankrupting his businesses, he is out of the game. Any bankrupt businesses a play has, goes to the persona or bank that he owes money to. The player who receives the bankrupt businesses immediately has to pay the bankruptcy charge plus 10% for any business he wants to own. If he does not pay the charges, the business goes back to the bank to be sold to anyone who lands on the square. Players may trade and sell businesses between themselves.

name.value: Monopoly: Pirates of the Caribbean On Stranger Tides Collector's Edition

item.description:
A pirate adventure awaits you in this special Pirates of the Caribbean collector’s edition of the monopoly game featuring pirate destinations from the new movie, On Stranger Tides. Do you have what it takes to outwit and outlast the legendary Pirates of the Caribbean as you buy, sell and trade prominent movie locations including Blackbeard’s Cabin, WhiteCap Bay, St. James Palace and the deadly Mermaid Pools? The fate of the high seas lies in your hands as you battle for ultimate control of the Fountain of Youth.

Includes 6 collectible tokens: Jack Sparrow’s compass, Jack Voodoo Doll, Angelica’s Ring, The Fountain of Youth Chalice, Mermaid Coffin, Sword of Triton.

item.description: Navigate our wonderful solar system in a race to collect research specimens! Your robot might encounter asteroids and malfunctioning rocket parts, or have some of our galaxy’s finest (and friendliest) lend you a helping hand in this quest to beat the rest! Your Robot races round the sun to all eight planets - every one has specimens that you must grab for research in your rocket lab, the first player to fill their science shelf wins!

On its adorable and happy game board, take a trip round to each vendor to gather some flowers, vegetables and more for your bounty of garden delights. Get your flower, herb and tree, vegetable and bird. (They're free!) Your garden is completely done? Get home first, and you have won!

From the back of the box :

"On the evening of July 1st. 1863, George Gordon Meade mounted his horse for the short ride north to the small Pennsylvania town of Gettysburg. Fighting had broken out early that morning. Meade had shifted the assorted corps of the Army of the Potomac northward to that town. General Reynolds was reported down. Hancock had the field in hand (he hoped) and Meade was now moving his headquarters to that fateful field. In the few days since being thrust into command of the Army of the Potomac, Meade had gained full control and would now direct it toward what was to be its single most important battle.

Turning back R.E. Lee's second invasion of the North, Meade would end the Southern general's significant offensive capabilities. For the North. it was the beginning of the march which would eventually win the war."

Scale
Each hex on the game map equals 200 yards of real terrain. Each day-time turn represents 30 minutes, each night turn one hour. The vertical scale between contours is 30 feet.
Infantry and cavalry units are brigades, artillery units usually 16 gun battalions. A strength point of infantry or cavalry is 100 men. A gun point of artillery is roughly 3 cannons.[...]

Orders
Orders are the heart of the main command system of this game series. Players prepare orders in writing as instructions to the corps (generally) as to what they are to do. An order is not a hex by hex record of movement. It is the actual wording in the same form as the historical orders."

Re-implemented by:

 Thunder at the Crossroads (second edition)

item.description:
Goal: Become the most dexterous one moving 11 small wooden dowels, separating one thing at a time


 Select one out of 4 different games:
 Grab all of them, form a fist and try to drop one thing at a time
 Place all of them in your open hand and let them roll down, one dowel at a time 
 Put all of them between your 'Praying Hands' and drop one thing at a time, keeping your thumbs together
 Fix all of them horizontally between your hands and drop one dowel at a time
 


Scoring: 1st dowel +1, 2nd dowel +3, 3rd dowel + 5 etc.


 Fix 2 dowels with one hand in parallel and use the others to build up a pile - the higher the more you score



 Combine the four blue plastic rings with the dowels, creating a higher challenge for the dexterity of the participants

Card game that can be played in 3 versions.

From the creators:

"War Kings is a card game modeled after the ancient warring times by which the rules and principles of the game are adopted from thirteen chapters of Sun Tzu's Art of War. In War Kings, the crux of the thirteen chapters are gathered and fully utilized, the function of each card is designed based on these principles."

There are 3 ways to play War Kings:

1) War Kings - The Battle!
Involves playing cards to attack/defend. You have 4 lives. Every time you win a battle you win terrain. Win 4 terrain you win the game, or if all other players run out of lives before you, you win the game. People can team up on attacks/defense
2) War Kings - The Duel!
Kind of like a complex version of war; cards battle with various cards having different effects on the battle.
3) War Kings - Enemy Attacks!
Rummy variant; want to run out of cards first and score points for cards played.

The first game can be played by 3 to 6 players utilizing the one game deck. The second game can be played by two using two separately purchased decks. The third game is a simpler game that can be played by 2 to 6 players.

The cards feature artwork, Chinese characters, and English text.

The game is a card game on Military History, where six questions are on the one side of a card and the appropriate answers on the back side. The questions are colorcoded into six categories:

1. Up to 1200 A.D.
2. The 18th and 19th Centuries 
3. Naval History 
4. Aviation History 
5. Personalities 
6. General Knowledge

There are three ways to play MILITARIA (from the box):
1. The cards can be used purely as a reference for a Military History Quiz with questions chosen at random.
2. Each player can attempt to answer all the questions on one card for 1 point each. Should they reach a certain level of correct answers on this card, then they continue their turn by answering the next card also. 
3. The cards can be used in conjunction with any comparable TRIVIAL game.

The box contains 200 cards with 6 questions each.

item.description:
Goal: Form a sentence from randomly drawn letters and a 'theme'-card, as quick as possible.

Build up the board - distribute the letters onto the coloured spaces

1. Draw a 'theme'-card out of different fields of topics
2. Use a six-sided coloured die and pick up corresponding letters
3. Form a sentence (simultaneously) , which must refer to the 'theme'-card - the faster the better, because only the first one scores;

Irish Wolf is a card game for 3-4 players published in spielbox 1992 #1. Game material: 25 play cards (each 5 in five different colors and values from 1 to 5) showing a figure of a Greyhound, 25 tokens (each five in five different colors) and chips (e. g., 20 of value 1 and 20 of value 5). The game is about a racing with Greyhounds and its progress can be influenced by the cards each player plays. The cards are shuffled and distributed to the players. The remaining card left is placed on the matching color group, causing the Greyhound of this color takes the lead of the racing. Thereafter, all players play simultaneously a card from their hands and the Greyhounds, then, move forwards according to the number on the respective cards. Players use the tokens to wager on a greyhound of your choice and the game ends when no token of one color is available. Players receive chips according to the their tokens of the same color of the winner dogs.

Pick up as many as possible 'sight-seeing' markers and souvenirs.
All the players have the same starting place - Lindau.
Depending on your amount of luck - and collecting a bonus for
being the first one who finishes the race - you are going to win.

1. Rotationally you travel along the red route - broken or continous line - as many stations as points diced with your meeple
2. You also may choose the blue (sea)line - you may switch from one to the other at any place where the lines meet
3. If your meeple lands in 'marked' cities - someting happens, depending on the color of the city - picking up souvenirs etc.
4. Meeting another player you are going to be invited getting a present (=souvenir)
5. First player who arrives back in Lindau receives 5 additional souvenirs
6. The winner is the one who has collected the most souvenirs, after all players have returned from the trip

In Cubulus you want to be the first player to create a square in your color on one side of the cube. Do this, and you win the game.

On a turn, you add a colored ball to the 3x3x3 playing area by pushing it into place – possibly pushing other balls out of the way – or change the order of balls in a completed row by pushing them one space, then reinserting the ball pushed out of the row. With two players, one color of balls is neutral. Keep your eyes on all sides of the cube to prevent others from squaring off for the win.

item.description:
Boulder Greenbelt is a game themed around life in the city of Boulder, Colorado. Spaces on the game board resemble actual places within the city and each space does something for or to the player akin to its real life counterpart.
At the beginning of the game players roll a die twice to determine their starting bankroll. This bankroll is not denoted by any type of token and is instead to be remembered in the players head or on paper. This is important as any player may contest a players bankroll at any time in the game and if it is found to be faulty that player suffers a punishment. Once all players have their bankroll play beings and each player rolls a die to move the indicated number of spaces and take the actions on the space on which they land.
A player wins when they achieve "Nirvanna" which can be achieved by a number of different means as they pass the 9th street bridge space.

This game was published in spielbox 1992 #1.
Each player has an 8x8 fields paper sheet, on which they should write words, using one field pro letter. The first player says a word with 3 to 5 letters and all players write this word on their sheets, one letter pro field, but only the consonants! The fields corresponding to vocals are kept empty. One can write the word where and how will, from the left to the right or from above to below. After all players have written this word, the next player says his word and the game proceeds in this way. If a player is unable to write a next word, he is out of the game. The aim of the game is writing the words in such a way, trying to have the fewest empty fields. Naturally, the words will have no sense after the empty fields have been filled.

This game was published in spielbox 1992 #2.
The game is played on a board with 61 hexagonal fields and each player starts with 31 pawns of different colors (e. g., white and black). Alternatively, each player places pawns on a still free field on the board. A player may indefinitely continue to place pawns on free fields which are neighbors of at least three of his own pieces. When it isn’t more possible, it is the turn of his opponent. The game ends after a player has placed his last pawn. This player is the winner and receives an amount of points corresponding to the opponent’s remaining pawns. There is a game variant, in which a player can choose between placing a pawn as described above or, alternatively, placing the next pawn on a distant field, preventing its occupation by a opponent’s pawn.

This game was published in spielbox 1992 #3 for celebrating the 25th Olympic Games - Barcelona 1992.

Two to four players compete on 8 special boards representing the 10 disciplines of the Decathlon: On day 1, they compete in 100m, long jump, shot put, high jump, and 400m. On day 2, the disciplines are: 110m hurdles, discus throw, pole vault, javelin throw, and 1500m. Special dice, with red, green and blue faces, are used by the players to achieve their successful results in each discipline. The points on the red faces are valid for racing events, those on blue faces for jumping events and the green faces for the launching events. Naturally, the winner, the super athlete, is the player with the most points at the end of the Decathlon.

A simple fast paced party game. Players use cards to build sets of four letter words.

Each player draws a card from the deck in an attempt to play a word. To play a word the player takes cards from his hand and places them face up covering the previous word to create a new one. The player can use as many cards as needed but Words may only consist of exactly four (4) letters and at least ONE letter must be used from the previous word.

Points are awarded the number of letters used and the complexity of the word.

A game for children. 4 is the ideal number of players.
Each player has set of five buckets which can be lifted by handles that fit under the rim, 5 marbles and a 'well'. The players each arrange their buckets in a row, one end of which touches the well.
Someone says "Go!", the player must lift the bucket closest to the well and tips the marble into the well. He returns the bucket , lifts the second one and tips the marble into the now empty first bucket. This procedure is repeated until the marble in the fifth bucket has been transferred into all the other buckets. The winner is the first player to get 5 marbles into the well.
Simple but will appeal to its age range. Adults should supervise because the youngest children might fancy eating a marble.

The theme of the game is an eating contest in a Taiwanese Snackbar.

"In this competition you will eat more than you can imagine as your competitors continually challenge you to shove even more in. Play your cards cleverly or the servers will serve you food until you fall from your seat. Let the competitors be the ones to fill up until they drop and the snack bar throne will be yours!"

The players add "dish"-cards or special cards to a common "order"-pile until one of them can´t (or won´t) add any more cards. Then that player has to "eat" the whole order by drawing the appropriate amount of cards from a draw pile. If he draws one (or more) of the "No More!"-cards, he accrues negative points and the round ends. 
The played cards are then set aside and new "No More"-cards are shuffled into the (now smaller) draw pile, making for an ever more tense experience as the contest goes into the later stages.
When one player has collected 3 negative points the game ends and the player with the smallest amount of negative points wins the game.

item.description:
From the back of the box:

"What do you waitin' for? With "In bocca al lupo" (Good luck in Italian) you can live with your friends all the fun of the TV program that entertains millions of TV viewers! Playing with "In bocca al lupo" it's easy and fun. The game is divided in a series of trials, each giving a prize in "Golden Tokens". To win you have to uncover the "Black Sheep", to guess the "Mysterious Word", to be "Beware of the Wolf" meanwhile you have to remember a sequence of names, to solve the "Gipsy"'s riddles without draw the black moon, to have star's lucky in the "Game of zodiac", and to find the winning ace in the final showdown "Two Versus All"".

It have cards, a wheel with an arrow, a wheel for the zodiac (it's static: 12 cards are drawn and put down around the wheel), block of papers and two book of riddles, good for ten plays.

name.value: Euro: In viaggio per l'europa con la nuova moneta unica
Euro: Auf der Reise durch Europa mit der neuen Einheitswährung

item.description:
From the back of the box:

"A trip across the EUROPE, both educational and fun, discovering of what will change with the introduction of the single currency. With a simple and gripping gameplay, you'll learn a lot of important notions, to be real EUROPE nationals and do the first shopping in EURO. Tailored for the whole family or group of friends who want to be prepared for this new important appointment.

Gameplay it's simple: Every player get an amount of fake money, and a "Travel Agency"; they puts two paws (one plastic, one cardboard with standup) one in a track where different thinks can happens, and one in a map of the European Union. Spinning the wheel, every player move the plastic pawn around the track, where it may get or lose money or tickets. Some special boxes on track are Quiz boxes, and other are "Guess the price" style: a player read from the quiz book a thing, and the others must guess what price is in euro, putting the money on the "Travel Agency" and opening all at the same time. A square in the track is "Departure" where all players, using tickets (train is a near country, boat are country connected by some naval lines, and plane are every non near coutry). After these moves, if there is only a pawn on a country, that player get a flag. If two or more are on that country, nobody gets that flag! Also, there are only three flag; when they are out, the player don't get the flag. Win who have 6 flags.
 
The game has playing board, rulesbook, triviabook, various pawns, 6 "Travel Agency" player's screen to hide information, flags, tickets and cardboard Euro money.

item.description:
This is a memory game for children age 4 and older. The players travel around the board collecting gifts. The cards matching each gift are placed in a plastic rack in front of the child... but the kids turn the cards away so only the other players can actually see the images.

The first player to collect seven gift cards and name them correctly in the proper order wins the game.

Includes a colorful board, 4 plastic racks, 4 tokens, 33 cards, a die, and the rules. No reading is required to play... the cards have images and descriptions but the kids can just remember the pictures.

"10 lively action games for one or more players"

A collection of 10 games played using the plastic "flickers" and "pucks" where you must flick the discs into various areas of the box insert. Sometimes into the coloured areas through the small gates or other parts of the scoring surface.

Games lists in the rules are -

Simplex
Colour Box
Form Fours
Colour Fours
Vicious Circle
Spider
Rainbow
Shepherd
Yellow Peril
Fairway

Rules are in English and French.

This is a set of miniatures wargame rules for refighting the english civil war.

The rules set is a derivative of WRG's DBA rules. The smallest unit is a "stand" containing multiple models as opposed to handling individual figures.

The emphasis of the rules is quick-play. Combat is resolved by the roll of two standard dice, and movement is controled by a single die roll for "Command Points".

The goal of the game is to collect and assemble parts of moms

the tiles represent moms in different colors and style.
Each mom is split in 3 parts (head, body and legs).

All the tiles are shuffled face down, this is the board.

Like in Memory we must remember were the tiles you want are, and you collect them to build hilarious moms.

A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from the Seine-Saint-Denis, in France.

Close to Pandemic, with an environmental theme.

In this cooperative game, players face five major crises (melting north pole, ocean pollution, deforestation, air pollution and human impact) and attempt to save the Planet.

Players must plan their strategy together to stop these crises.

There is no specialists, but players draw a number of cards depending of their location, they can travel and use their cards as abilities to cure crisis.

It's an educational themed game to educate children about environmental issues.

Game from the TV show of the same name on Gulli.

Two teams compete in different fun and educational tests (mime, quizz, songs) to earn time for the final.

for the final, teams confronte "the black box" with the time they earn during the first step of the game.
each team lead a blindness member who try to take some cubes from the box.

From the back of the box:

Will you get to the wedding on time? Follow your heart and nothing is impossible!

A simple set of rules, short duration of play and bright illustrations offer excitement and fun for young Thumbelina fans. With the added surprise of chance cards, children learn to identify pictures and colors while enjoying the fantasy world of Thumbelina and her charming prince, Cornelius.

Object: Try to be the first player to get to Thumbelina's wedding.

On your turn, roll the color die and move to the first space that matches the color rolled. If there is another player on that space, that player must go back to the start.

If you roll white, take the top chance card. Find the matching picture on the board and move to the space beside it. Sometimes this will enable you to jump ahead, but other times you will have to move backwards.

To win you must land on the orange space at the end of the trail and you must roll orange to do so.

In Fame Us, each player starts the game with six cards, with the cards bearing descriptive words or phrases like "tall", "blonde", "actor", "politician" or "mustachioed". On a turn, a player can either:


 Play a card to the center of the table. Ideally this player has someone famous in mind who matches all the descriptive cards now in play – but no names need be mentioned at this point.
 Pass and draws a card.
 Challenge the previous player who played a card to name someone who fits the descriptions in play. If this player names someone, everyone votes (except the challenger) whether or not this person is an acceptable answer. If the challenger lose, he draw two cards. If the bluffer loses, he draws three cards.


To keep players honest in their voting, at the start of the game each player is secretly assigned to one of two teams: "The VIP Table" or "The King on the Dance Floor". The game ends after ten rounds or after one player has emptied his hand of cards. The team with the fewest cards in hand wins.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet

item.description:
Card game with no luck where each player plays with either hearts, spades, clubs or diamonds. So each player has a set of 13 cards, and each set has the same value. The players clockwise play a card and try to win sticks, but the sticks are individually not worth the same amount of points. The first stick is worth 1 point + 1 point for every card played in this stick. The winner of the second stick receives 2 points for the stick + 1 point for every card in that stick and so on. When one player plays his last card it is the last stick, and thereafter the results are calculated.

This card game was invented by Dan Glimne in 1991 inspired by the Swedish parliament elections at that time. It was published in his book Nya spel (1994) and later also in Kortspelshandboken (2005) and Lilla Korstspelshandboken (2006).

Card game where each player is a runner in a 100 meter race. The cards (ordinary deck of 52 cards) are shuffled and each player receives 13 cards face down. The players now look at them and sort out 4 cards and from these 4 cards he decides whether to use 1,2,3 or all 4 of them to use in the race. They are used to determine the result of the player. Spades are not allowed to use among these 4 cards. They are instead among the the rest of the cards (9 cards) which are placed face down in front of the player. If a player accuses another player for being doped, he then chooses to look at one (or maybe 2 or up to 4 cards depending on how many cards the player used for the race) of his 9 face down cards, and if any of these cards is a spade, the player is doped and disqualified.

This card game was invented by Dan Glimne in 1988 inspired by Ben Johnson´s Olympic doping scandal at that time. It was published in Spielbox magazine (1989), Games Review Monthly (1989), Dan Glimne book, Nya Spel (1994) and later also in Kortspelshandboken (2005) and Lilla Korstspelshandboken (2006). It was also published in a Swedish Daily Newspaper (1988).

Avoid to spend the most valuable tokens of your collection for building 'waste pyramids', because the remaining ones are going to score

1 place your - different sized - tokens on the board corresponding to the roll of three dice; chose the most favourable one to build a back-up-system for your more precious tokens
2 form 'waste pyramids' (all together) to reduce the supply of your opponents - also by the roll of three dice

This game was published in spielbox 1992 #4.
From 2 to 6 players try to build the surface of a new planet. Each player gets a copy of the board and a felt-tip pen of different color. In the first phase, the players, alternately, put a mark of their colors on a free field of the board in order to show their ownership. This phase lasts different rounds depending on the numbers of players (7 rounds for 2 players, 5 for 3 players, 4 rounds for 4-5 players and 3 for 6 players. In the next phase, each player, in his turn, determines a direction and expands his landscape (for example, blue = water) in this direction. The game ends when all fields are filled. The player who has occupied the shortest amount of fields receives zero point. The other players receive points corresponding to the difference between the number of fields they occupied and the number of fields the last player has.

This game was published in spielbox 1992 #4.

Two players duel on a special board of 12 round fields linked by 12 lines. Alternately, each player places one of his pieces, numbered from 1 to 6, on a still free field. When all fields are occupied, the game ends. The aim of the game is to dominate the majority of the 12 lines that connect the fields. A line is considered dominated, if the sum of the points of a player’s tokens on this line is higher than of the opponent.

A ball/marble rolling game published in the 1920s by Glevum Games.

It has at least three printings, one with the company name and wooden balls, one with the trademarked company name and logo(still with wooden balls) and a later printing with glass marbles and a different scoring target.

Early version used wooden balls and had 13 scoring holes numbered from 5 to 50 - (1x5, 3x10, 2x15m 2x20, 2x25, 2x30, 1x50) as depicted on the box cover.

The later version used glass marbles and had 20 scoring holes (4 x 5 pattern) numbered 5 to 20 - (4x5, 8x10, 6x15, 2x20)

Play appears to be that each player (any number) rolls 4 balls towards the target and scores the total of the numbers where the balls settle.

Double points are awarded should a ball settle in a hole of the same colour as the ball.

Play stops when somebody reaches 100 points.

This game was published in spielbox 1992 #5.

Ascot is board game about a horse racing for 2 to 18 players. Game components: the game board (six racing lines – one for each horse, numbered columns, representing forwards or backwards movements), 6 horses in 6 different colors, 108 betting slips (each 18 in the colors of the horses), 72 movement cards in neutral color. For each horse, there are 12 cards (3x "+", 2x "++", 1x "+++", 3x "-", 2x "- -", and 1x "- - -"). The start position of each horse is the field of its respective line in the central column. Each player gets six betting slips (one of each color) and an amount of the 72 movement cards, previously shuffled and distributed among them. The objective of the players is to give adequate movement cards to the player nominated as game Master, trying to influence the position of the horses during the racing. Simultaneously, the players may change betting slips with each other, trying to achieve the best winnings. For that, the players are free to communicate among them and change both betting slips and movement cards. During the racing, the players can give to the game Master movement cards, face down. After each five cards are so played, the Master moves the corresponding horses according to these movement cards. The game ends after a predetermined number of rounds played and the players receive points according to their bets.

Donkey It's a Kick! has just come out with its beautiful 2nd Edition packaging and high-quality cards to withstand the excitement that this game generates!

1. Place one less puck in the middle of the table than there are players.
2. Dealer reads aloud the instructions on the Kicker Card, which will explain the challenge for this round of play. Dealer then deals the PLAYING CARDS accordingly.
3. While fulfilling the challenge of the Kicker Card, each player races to get the qualifying hand to grab the first puck from the table. If a player grabs a puck, each remaining player must quickly try to grab a puck. One player will come up short. That player scores the letter "D" on their score card.
5. Once a player's score card spells D-O-N-K-E-Y, that player is officially out of the game, but is allowed to remain in play and wreak havoc on the remaining players in an effort to take them down with him.

You won't get bored with this game! Each Kicker Card challenge makes every round unique! In addition, players get to "police" other players and give them an unwanted letter score if they "slip up." Seasoned players of 8 or even 9 at a table will have this game over in 45 minutes or less! Once there's a D-O-N-K-E-Y in the game, the players start dropping like flies. There may only be one champion, but everyone walks away a winner with this game! Absolutely as much fun to lose as it is to win!

from game website

Are you steady enough to work at this fun fruit stand? Spin the wheel, then use the jumbo tweezers to pick or place fruit. In Avalanche Fruit Stand players are stacking small fruit-figures on a pile with the goal to not be the one who causes it to tumble.

Includes 40 fruit counters (5 different fruits), 2 jumbo tweezers, picture spinner, and adjustable cardboard fruit stand/storage box measuring 6"L x 9.5"W x 13.75"H

Objective:
To gain more knowledge of the life and personality of the prophet.

To play each player takes a game card, and as questions about the Prophet Ezra Taft Benson are shared. Players who have the answer on their game card put a marker on that spot. First one to have four markers in a row wins.

Goal: Collect as many chips as possible before 1st player goes bankrupt

1. Each player receives 10 wooden chips 
2. Place your 'chip-team' by rolling three dice into your own area
3. Prepare your team to challenge your opponents - roll the dice if you win ==> rolling a '6', you may collect set chips
4. If you own only one last chip (=letzter Dollar) you may play 'all or nothing'

Goal: Be the first to reach your inner circled areas with all of your tokens (alike Pachisi)


 You start within your coloured area at the outer range with 4 tokens (each of the tribes are named - from dark to bright: Normans, Anglo-Saxons, Britons and Picts & Scotti).
 Roll the three dices and allocate numbers to appropriate tokens - you may add up, too. Rolling doubles enables you to roll the dice again.
 Follow up the arrows

Madeira is an island officially discovered early in the 15th century by Portuguese seafarers. Madeira, the Portuguese word for wood, refers to the dense forest that covered its wild, fertile landscape. This, and its strategic position far into the Atlantic Ocean made the island one of the most significant Portuguese discoveries. Madeira served as a “laboratory” for what would become the Portuguese Empire.

Wheat plantations were the first means for survival on the island. After that, when D. Henrique decided to increase the economy of the Empire, sugar became the core business of Madeira. Once sugar started coming from other places in the world, such as Africa and Brazil, profits from sugar were no longer enough, and production of the very famous Madeira wine became the most important economic product of the island.

Players try to adapt themselves to these constraints, working to find better fields for farming the right goods and for obtaining precious wood, essential for erecting new structures in the cities and for building ships. In turn, the ships are crucial for trading in foreign markets, as well as for taking part in new expeditions to discover other countries.
Madeira has been established just as it was in the original administrative division of the island under 3 captaincies (Funchal, Machico, and Porto Santo), where the ultimate goal is to develop the Island, gaining the most prestige under and for the Portuguese Crown.

The Crown of Portugal has a series of requests regarding expeditions, urbanization, opening trade routes, increasing wealth, and controlling the guilds on the islands. Three times during the game, the players gain prestige for fulfilling certain requests by the Crown. At two other times, the Crown requests that the islands change the focus of their agriculture due to the changes in the world.

Players must carefully choose the correct timing to show their achievements. Too early and you don’t gain as much prestige, too late and you risk someone else stealing the best opportunities. Will you have what it takes to excel in all of these endeavors?
Beware, wheat may become scarce, money is never enough, the population is hungry, and the shadow of piracy looms large….

item.description:
2 - 5 players take turns laying down cards in a central pile. Instead of the basic suits found in a standard deck of cards, dabong! uses Earth, Wind, Water, and Fire.

The most common way a player lays down a card is by matching the suit or number of the card in the pile to a card in the player's hand. However, there are additional options to play the players can play cards of the same suit that add up to the number in the middle. For example, if a 10 of Fire is in the central pile, a player could play a 2, a 3, and a 5 of Water all at the same time.

A player wins when he/she has used all of his/her cards, or through a dabong! A dabong occurs when a players cards add up to the central card, regardless of suit.

item.description:
Translated from the box:
"Master Imagem is a game of question and answers which involves knowledge, luck and perception. There are 1800 questions divided in 6 subjects and your team can chose one of them and answer before the time ended.
Getting a right answer your team opens a door of the chosen theme and see a word or part of the mysterious figure. But if you are wrong, the next team gets a shot.
Collect more tips and risk a guess 'What?', 'Where?' or 'Who' is the mystery picture."

This Monopoly clone is themed with Canadian-based Tim Horton's "coffee and bake shops". Players buy and sell the restaurant's most popular items. Player tokens include (among others) a coffee cup, a donut, and a "Zamboni" ice resurfacing machine. (Tim Horton was a famous NHL hockey player).

A boardgame about the would-be Battle of the Falkland, designed in Spring 1982 while the British fleet was approaching the Argentina-occupied islands and the battle was still to be engaged. Published with some delay (because of a strike at the publishing house) on the Italian news magazine "Il Mondo" of the 4th of May, just while the battle raged.
A simplified aero-naval simulation boardgame, with the classical hex-grid map and square counters.

Soccer simulation published on the 5th of July, 1982 by the Italian weekly newsmagazine Panorama. Counters cover all the teams taking part in the World Cup in these same days.
The game is a classical simulation with hex-grid map, counters with attack and movement scores, charts for the results of confrontations and actions. The attack points have been awarded by a pool of famed Italian sport journalists.

From publisher:

Storyteller is a good workout for beginning storytellers. Making up stories is one of the most exciting activities in the world. It doesn’t matter whether it’s a campfire story or a $200 million blockbuster movie. There is only one winner in Storyteller but every player takes away an amazing prize - a unique story that they all created together.

The game set for Storyteller contains 200 cards which are divided into two different types: plot and ending cards. Plot cards contain elements of the future story: the heroes, places, objects, events and other characteristics. Each ending card has a final sentence for the story written on them. When developing a story, the players illustrate it by taking plot cards from their hands and placing them onto the table. As the game progresses, players take turns telling the story. Each player is trying to steer the tale in a direction that would ultimately fit their ending card. Since the ending cards are all quite different, each player will attempt to tailor the story in a different way, causing the plot to take notorious twists and turns.

item.description:
The Story: The year is 1702. As a humble bean farmer, you have grown restless and yearn for adventure. You gather your belongings, sell your farm and purchase a small sloop from the local shipyard. With entrepreneurial vigor, you set sail for the nearest island, hoping to turn a meager profit on your final barrel of beans. The leaders of your nation soon hear of your courage and petition your service. They provide you with a small satchel of gold, a crew, and Letters of Marque. As a newly commissioned privateer, you must navigate the treacherous seas, and bring home great riches and glory to your country of origin.

Gameplay: A player’s turn begins by drawing one adventure card and selecting one action card. Depending on the type of adventure, the card may be resolved immediately (e.g. a group activity), or the card may be placed on the ocean map by the player. The player then sails to an island or ocean space, choosing to either experience an adventure, or trade in the market. The market is the heart of this game. Players aim to buy low, sell high, carefully watching future prices, hoping to turn a profit. The action cards provide one-time bonuses to fight pirates, escape disasters, trade in the market, etc. Gold is used to upgrade ships, explore shipwrecks, gamble, etc. The game ends when a player’s ship is upgraded to level 10, and victory goes to the player with the most gold.

There’s a running battle in the Retirement home! The confrontations between the Gang of Kniters and the Gang of the Bakers become a Gangland exe- cution. Don’t be surprised... These Grandmas are the worst villains of this world.

Bad Grandmas is an irreverent trick-taking game for two players. Anticipation and strategy are key to this game, since every trick determines the conditions of the next. Therefore, the players have to think twice about their moves.

Object of the game: Collect the highest number of Cookies by winning as many Duels as possible.

(see below for the download-able PDF)

Translation from back of the box:

The board game CONDUCTEUR aims to familiarize the players with the road safety code and the laws that govern it. The situations presented correspond to the reality that drivers and future drivers will face.

The goal of each player is: get the least possible offense due to his negligence or imprudence for they result in the accumulation of demerit points and expensive fines . The player thus becomes well aware of the benefits of driving with vigilance and attention.

Eight (8) players can take part in the game. They receive initially a driver's license with 0 demerit points. The player who accumulates 15 demerit points will have his license revoked and will be removed from the game. Whoever ends the game with the best record will win.

From the outset, all drivers are insured under a policy of "basic liability insurance" covering damage to their vehicle when they are the victims of an accident for which they are not responsible for, covering the damage to others.

name.value: Killer Bunnies and the Conquest of the Magic Carrot

item.description:
Find the Magic Carrot and claim ultimate glory in Killer Bunnies and the Conquest of the Magic Carrot, the follow-up to Killer Bunnies and the Quest for the Magic Carrot; Conquest can be played on its own or combined with the Quest blue starter game (and its boosters).

Your goal: Keep your bunnies alive, while eliminating your opponents' bunnies with whimsical and sometimes very deadly weapons! Other players will stop at nothing to keep you from collecting carrots and taking the win, in this game that is full of spoofs, parodies and hysterical references. Conquest will have you plotting your strategy (not to mention your revenge), managing your resources, crossing your fingers, bartering with the enemy, and doing whatever it takes to claim the Magic Carrot and win the game!

Killer Bunnies and the Conquest of the Magic Carrot: Red Booster Deck
Killer Bunnies and the Conquest of the Magic Carrot: Violet Booster Deck
Killer Bunnies and the Quest for the Magic Carrot

item.description:
Is is a set of 58 colored tiles, small discs and cardboard cards (like bingo)that enable players to play a number of different games: Nu Monte Carlo Blocks, Poker, Rhumy (sic) Dominoe (sic), Cassino (sic), checkers, Color Lotto, Hoo Doo and Color Blocks.

Rules for Nu Monte Carlo Blocks: "To start the game a dealer is chosen. The blocks are placed on the table same as dominoes, face down and are shuffled. Each player draws one block starting from the right of the dealer. When a Red block is drawn, the drawer neither puts or takes from the kitty. When Green block is drawn the player places one chip in the kitty. When a Yellow block is drawn the player places two chips in the kitty.

"TO WIN, the player getting the first three in a row of same color receives three chips from the kitty. The player getting first four in a row of the same color receives four from the kitty. The player getting first five in a row of same color receives all the chips in the kitty. At no time is a winner to pay any chips to the kitty."

If that makes sense to you please explain it to me. Rules for other games are included in the images section.

First of "Il Bel Paese", a collection of monthly issues appearing in Italian newspaperkiosks from late 1985. Each is a boardgame inspired by news.
"Business - Il gioco del potere" ("Business- The game of Power") depicts on its map a square grid featuring the most important public and private companies. The size in squares is larger for the most influential ones. Players put counters of their colors to control squares and when they circle a whole area, as in a kind of Go, they gain total control of it taking away all the opponents' counters. Event cards influence the deployement. Duels are done with green and red cards in a kind of "prisoner's dilemma".

Another day, another mammoth hunt. But the spoils of the hunt remains to be divided, and everyone tries to secure the largest share for themselves in this quick and clever family strategy game. Each round the tiles are shuffled in the bag and dropped onto the table. The face up symbols show the spoils of today's hunt. 
 The tiles are then divided by a unique mechanic: When it is your turn, you may either A) Take any number of tiles from the pool, or B) Claim that another player has been too greedy, taking all of that player's tiles, but returning at least one tile to the pool (you must of course show yourself to be a little less greedy).

The next player without tiles then follows in turn. This way the size of the pool will gradually increase, and the round is over once the last player without tiles decides to take what's left in the pool. Every player will then have a share of tiles, and a scoring phase follows.

Tactical play will help you get the meat, fur, tusks, animals, and tools you want (each tile has a different way of scoring), but you may also play cards for immediate effects or to secretly influence the scoring.

- Game material is language independent -

item.description:
Crisloid Plastics 5 Game Set is a collection of dice and two dice cups for 5 different dice games.

Has a total of 25 d6 dice for the following games:
- 10 Pin Bowling (10 dice with a bowling pin on 1 face, 5 sides blank)
- Poker (5 dice with 10, 10, J, Q, K, Spade) 
- Jack-Pot (3 dice with Bell, Lemon, Orange, Bar, Lime, Cherry)
- 5 regularly numbered dice (has rules for Craps)
- Put & Take (2 dice with A, 1, 2, 3, 3, 4 on 1 and T, T, T, P, P, P on the other).

Put and Take is a betting game where each player puts in equal amount into the pot. You then roll the dice and you put or take the number rolled. If you roll a T and an A, you take all from the pot and win.

Jack-Pot has a payout table in the rules that pays for certain rolls. For example 3 bars pays out 20 to 1, while bar-lemon-cherry equals a free roll.

Simple roll and move game with a space theme. Players race their rocketships, trying to be the first to orbit the moon and safely return to earth.

You roll a single D6 and move that many spaces, certain spaces have bonuses or penalties.

components: game rules, game board, 4 plastic rockets, 1 D6

SHOOT! is a soccer card game for two players. The game is played with 55 cards. The set consists of 30 soccer player cards, 2 keeper cards, 2 placement cards, 20 action cards and 1 game rules card.
Every player has a team. The team consist of 15 soccer players and a keeper.

In the upper right corner of every soccer player card are one to three soccer balls. This is the value of this soccer player for it's placement line. The value of the keeper is per action determined with a die. The higher total value in a line allows more shot (die rolls) at the goal.

The 20 action cards are used by both players.

subtitled: "wargaming rules for 28mm science fiction miniatures" this is one of several rules-sets introduced by small/independent companies to allow gamers to play miniatures games in a more realistic "science fiction" setting, rather than the "science fantasy" setting that a leading miniatures gaming company adopted.

B&W ringbound rulebook

A very light and simple two players card game by Bruno Faidutti, it has been published successively, each time with some additions and developmenst, in the French magazines Sciences & Vie Découverte (1999), then in the Japanese boardgame magazine Gamelink (2011), and last in the French comics magazine Lanfeust, in 2016.

The Battle of Gods is a variation on the good old game of War, which tries to add some subtleties, both with tactics and bluffing.
The first new idea is that cards are played in pairs. First, each player plays a card. Cards are revealed, and then each player plays a second one, and their values are added. This makes for some interesting dilemmas.
The second new idea is that there are 6 sets of 12 cards, for six different mythologies. In each game, each player plays a different mythology. In each set, two or three cards have special effects when played, making for interesting combos and even more bluffing.
It's a two player game, but the six available mythologies make for 15 different possible duels.

A Fistful of TOWs 3 is a fast-playing battalion- to brigade/regiment-level game using miniatures. Game covers mid-1930s to 2015, and army lists from WW2 and post-war eras. Each stand represents a platoon. Can be played with miniatures from 2mm up to 15mm with no modifications; for larger miniatures authors suggest possibly changing ground scale. Design ground scale is 1"=100m, can be played using 1cm=100m without altering any numbers. Nominal turn length is 12 minutes, but for infantry heavy games 20 or 30 minutes per turn is probably more accurate.
Game features: 
- Troop quality is very important
- Simple command rules
- Includes a full battle-generator campaign system.
- WW2 comprehensive data and army lists for Germany, USA, UK, France, and Poland. Authors will be releasing Italian data and army lists as a free expansion.
- Modern data on over 1000 post-war armored vehicles, artillery, helicopters, etc.
- Modern army lists for US Army 1950-2015, Russian Army 1970-2015, most of the NATO allies in the 1980s-1990s, Arab-Israeli wars in 1967 and 1973, Australia 1966-2015, and North Vietnam/Vietcong 1964-1973.
- Includes rules for airstrikes, airborne and amphibious assaults, helicopters, chemical weapons, tactical nukes.
- Formatted for easy reading.
- 458 pages including: 104 pages of core rules, 26 pages of supplemental rules, 96 pages of army lists, 128 pages of vehicle/gun/infantry/aircraft data, 18 pages of scenario/campaign design and system, quick reference charts, introduction, detailed table of contents, index, etc.

Vorbeugen und Helfen (English: Prevention and Help) is a learning game for children to gain strength in dangerous situations.

Idea and aim of "Prevention and Help" is to caution children to crimes. Children should know what danger lays in several situations. They should 

 gain knowledge about these possible dangerous situations 
 experience solidarity and helpfulness 
 learn self-confidence 
 learn power of sustenance 
 learn to communicate 




The possible dangerous situations may be:

 DANGER AT THE DOOR 
 ENCOUNTER ON THE ROAD 
 A CHILD GETS LOST 
 AWAKING OF JEALOUSY AND TEMPTATION 
 BURGLARY AT THE SWIMMINGPOOL 
 BICYCLE BURGLARY 
 THE ORPHANT APARTMENT 
 PARKING VACATION CAR 
 INCITEMENT OF ROBBERY 
 BLACKMAIL 
 DANGEROUS MOTORBYC DRIVING 
 PLAYING WITH FIRE 




How to play: 
A tile is chosen and placed face-down in the middle of the table. Adjacent to it the pile of shuffled Prevent- and Helpcards. Every player takes 3 Prevent-/Helpcards (placing them face-up in front of each player), 2 prevent thaler and 2 help thaler.
When the tile is turned face-up the communication process starts.

The game components include:
12 game tiles about dangerous situations 
72 Prevention and Helpcards 
20 Prevention Thaler "Smiling Policeman" 
20 Help Thaler "Serious Policeman" 
Appraisal Chits

The card game Oz, based on the L. Frank Baum novel The Wonderful Wizard of Oz, contains two decks of cards: one a character deck with nine copies each of Dorothy, Toto the dog, the Scarecrow, the Lion, the Tin Man, the Good Witch, the Wicked Witch and the Wizard of Oz, and the other a story deck, with each story card explaining how to score points at the end of the game, e.g., each pairing of Dorothy and the Lion scores two points, while having the majority of Witch cards is worth eight points.

The game lasts 8—9 rounds, and at the start of each round, the players draw cards from the decks to create n+1 columns (where n is the number of players), with each column having two character cards and one story card. Each player chooses one column, placing the story card on the table and the character cards in his hand. From the fifth round on, a player can have only four story cards in front of him, so each time he chooses a column, he must discard a story card from his collection. After the final round, players reveal their character cards and tally their points to see who wins.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable
